channel.title: The 2011 Open Championship
channel.generator: Sitecore CMS: http://www.sitecore.net. Sitecore RSS module: Img.Common.Rss, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null

item.title: R&A announces changes to Open entry criteria
item.description: The R&A has announced changes to the entry criteria for next year’s Open Championship at Royal Lytham & St Annes.

item.title: Clarke nominated for BBC Sports Personality of the Year
item.description: Open Champion Darren Clarke has been shortlisted for this year's BBC Sports Personality of the Year award.

item.title: Kent benefits from £77 million Open Championship
item.description: Independent economic research commissioned by Open Championship organiser, The R&A, highlights that this year’s Championship staged at Royal St George’s Golf Club delivered a £77 million benefit to the County of Kent.

item.title: Jacklin reflects on his Open win and rates England’s 2012 contenders
item.description: It is now well over 40 years since Tony Jacklin won the 1969 Open Championship at Royal Lytham & St Annes but it is not an occasion the Englishman or his legion of fans will ever forget.

item.title: 2012 Open tickets on sale now
item.description: Book your place at the 2012 Open Championship

item.title: St Andrews green credentials recognised
item.description: St Andrews has become the first Open Championship venue to be formally recognised for its commitment to sustainable golf course management.

item.title: Open Silver Medallist Lewis secures maiden professional victory
item.description: Open Championship Silver Medallist Tom Lewis has won his maiden title at the Portugal Masters, in only his third professional start.

item.title: Stars of tomorrow learn from today’s Open Champion
item.description: Darren Clarke hosted his foundation’s first “Champions Weekend” at Portmarnock since his victory in July’s Open Championship.

item.title: The Open Championship returns to the Old Course in 2015
item.description: The Open will return to the Home of Golf in 2015 when the 144th Championship is played at St Andrews from 16-19 July.

item.title: Matsuyama earns Open 2012 IFQ spot after Asian Amateur victory
item.description: Hideki Matsuyama has won the third Asian Amateur Championship with a superb final round 67 at The Singapore Island Country Club.

item.title: Ralph Lauren become Official Patron of the Open Championship
item.description: Ralph Lauren has signed a five-year partnership with The R&A to become an Official Patron of The Open Championship until July 31, 2016.

item.title: The R&A announces change to Open Championship Final Qualifying
item.description: The R&A has announced changes to the Final Qualifying stage of The Open Championship.

item.title: Clarke turns back the years with sensational Open win
item.description: Darren Clarke is The 2011 Open Champion

item.title: Door to Open glory opens for Clarke
item.description: Dustin Johnson, one of the longest hitters in the game, opened the door to Open glory for Darren Clarke.

item.title: Johnson steps up to his challenge
item.description: Dustin Johnson closes in on the lead

item.title: Webb Simpson tops the rookies
item.description: Webb Simpson won the battle of the rookies when he closed with a 73 to claim a top-20 finish at the 140th Open Championship at Royal St George’s.

item.title: Mickelson miss restores Clarke's two shot advantage
item.description: Darren Clarke is doggedly hanging on to his two-shot lead over Phil Mickelson.

item.title: Clarke shakes off the Mickelson challenge
item.description: Phil Mickelson briefly shared the top of the leaderboard with Darren Clarke.

item.title: Mickelson is the man on the move
item.description: Darren Clarke still heads the Championship on five under par, but behind him everything is changing.

item.title: Tom Lewis joins an elite group as Silver Medal winner
item.description: Tom Lewis joined an elite group when he closed with a 74 to win the Silver Medal.

item.title: Clarke and Johnson get their final rounds under way
item.description: For Dustin Johnson and Darren Clarke the long wait before their final rounds in the 140th Open Championship is over.

item.title: Early honours to Sergio in his battle with Rory
item.description: Rory McIlroy and Garcia, two of the game's brightest and most charismatic players, are paired together.

item.title: Cink turns the clock back
item.description: Stewart Cink braving the tough conditions well

item.title: Adverse weather can’t dampen Open enthusiasm
item.description: The course at Royal St George’s continues to present the excellent conditions expected of the host venue of golf’s oldest Major.

item.title: Mickelson’s new approach is working
item.description: “Leftie” goes into the final round just five shots off the pace.

item.title: Early starters finding birdie opportunities
item.description: Spencer Levin started his final round in The Open close to the tail of the field at 8.20 this morning.

item.title: Johnson hoping to power his way to victory
item.description: Dustin Johnson will have power on his side when he starts out on the final round of the 140th Open Championship.

item.title: Clarke battling against the odds
item.description: Darren Clarke does not have the odds on his side when he tees up in the final round of this year’s Open Championship.

item.title: Clarke and Johnson look to break their Major duck
item.description: Darren Clarke and Dustin Johnson head into the final round of the 140th Open Championship hoping to exorcise ghosts of their golfing past.

item.title: Different ways to tackle majors Sunday
item.description: There are as many ways to prepare for the final day of The Open Championship as there are players in contention.

item.title: Clarke gets another chance to win elusive Open title
item.description: Darren Clarke holds a slender one stroke lead at the end of the third day at Royal St George's.

item.title: Tight race for amateur medal
item.description: It looks like the race for the Silver Medal, which is awarded to the leading amateur at The Open Champions, could go all the way.

item.title: Clarke holds on to one shot lead at the turn
item.description: Darren Clarke holds a precarious one shot lead as he reaches the turn in the third round of the Championship in level par to remain at four under.

item.title: Fowler produces a sensational 68 to close within sight of the leaders
item.description: America’s Rickie Fowler produced one of the finest rounds in recent Open history when he battled through a strong wind and driving rain to card a two under 68.

item.title: Oosthuizen refuses to give up hope
item.description: Louis Oosthuizen has not given up hope of retaining the Open title he claimed in such style 12 months ago.

item.title: Laughing in the Rain
item.description: America’s Bo Van Pelt explained how to play well in the wind and the rain after carding a fine three over par 73 during the third round of the 140th Open Championship at Royal St George’s.

item.title: Watson sets the pace with a stunning round
item.description: It seems that nothing can stop Tom Watson, not age, not atrocious weather conditions, not even a slightly suspect touch on the shorter putts.

item.title: Fowler moves in the right direction
item.description: Rickie Fowler is starting to make a move up the leaderboard as the weather continues to play havoc

item.title: McIlroy struggling for birdie opportunities
item.description: McIlroy struggling to get going

item.title: Oosthuizen takes time out to support future champions
item.description: Louis Oosthuizen, the 2010 Open Champion, knows the value of supporting young people to help them get into golf and develop as people.

item.title: The weather causes havoc for early starters
item.description: Last night a total of 18 golfers posted sub-par totals after two difficult days at Royal St George’s.

item.title: Watson defying the odds
item.description: Defying the odds, 61-year-old Tom Watson, is calling on all the experience gained in 33 previous Opens.

item.title: Lawrie succumbs to the killing zone
item.description: Scotland’s Paul Lawrie carded a triple bogey on the 495-yard par-4 fourth hole this morning.

item.title: Birdies are rare
item.description: There are just two tiny flashes of red on the scoreboards so far this morning as the first eight groups set out for their third rounds.

item.title: Clarke’s birdie blitz helps him to top the leaderboard
item.description: Spectators looking to watch some exciting golf over the weekend might want to seek out the games involving Darren Clarke, Thomas Bjorn, Charl Schwartzel and George Coetzee.

item.title: Big crowds flock to The Open - direct train eases the flow
item.description: Attendance figures for the week so far are high.

item.title: Great day's play in store
item.description: Over two days on a tough links course, with wind and rain forecast, a seven shot swing is not only possible it is probable.

item.title: Clarke and Glover top crowded leaderboard
item.description: The leaderboard is packed so tight at the end of the second day of the 140th Open Championship that 18 players are within three strokes of the joint leaders.

item.title: Veteran Americans to the fore
item.description: Fifty two year old American, Tom Lehman, carded a second round three under par 67.

item.title: Sad McDowell could head home after a second round collapse
item.description: Looks like McDowell will miss the cut after miserable round of 77

item.title: Bjorn battles to stay in touch
item.description: An up and down round from Thomas Bjorn keeps him well in contention at 3-under

item.title: Lewis drops but stays in the hunt
item.description: Tom Lewis will have mixed emotions as he sits down to have his supper this evening.

item.title: Early finishers may have the advantage
item.description: Lunch will be tasting particularly good for Darren Clarke and Lucas Glover.

item.title: Clarke comes in under the radar.
item.description: Darren Clarke, is no longer Northern Ireland’s top-ranked golfer but he has to claimed a share of the early clubhouse lead on four under par 136.

item.title: Three opening birdies put Dyson at the head of the field
item.description: Simon Dyson has opened his second round in spectacular fashion with birdies at each of the first three holes to take the outright lead at five under.

item.title: Bjorn still in front after a muted second morning
item.description: Thomas Bjorn might well have been slightly surprised this morning when he surveyed the early second round scores at the 140th Open Championship.

item.title: Watson holes in one as Lewis falters
item.description: One bounce and straight in the hole was the way Tom Watson handled the 178-yard sixth hole this morning.

item.title: Putting for dough
item.description: Anyone who disputes the fact that putting is the most important part of the game of golf might want to have a quick look at the putting statistics collated during the first round of this year’s Championship.

item.title: A tough piece of real estate
item.description: The 419-yard par-4 fifth was the toughest hole on the course yesterday

item.title: A day in the sun for Darren Clarke
item.description: This is something of a renaissance year for Darren Clarke, the 42-year-old heavyweight from Northern Ireland.

item.title: Bobby Jones was the only amateur to lead - and win
item.description: Interest in amateur golfers spiked yesterday when young Tom Lewis joined Thomas Bjorn in the Championship lead.

item.title: Bobby Jones was the only amateur to lead - and win
item.description: Interest in amateur golfers spiked yesterday when young Tom Lewis joined Thomas Bjorn in the Championship lead.

item.title: Glover joins the leaders at five under
item.description: In the calm and sunny conditions of the Championship's second morning Lucas Glover has birdied the second hole to join overnight leaders Thomas Bjorn and Tom Lewis at the head of the field at five under.

item.title: Lewis enters new territory with a smile on his face
item.description: Tom Lewis set out on the most important round of his young life this morning when he teed up at 9.31 alongside Tom Watson and Henrik Stenson.

item.title: Lewis enters new territory with a smile on his face
item.description: Tom Lewis set out on the most important round of his young life this morning when he teed up at 9.31 alongside Tom Watson and Henrik Stenson.

item.title: Scene set for an exciting second day
item.description: Scotland’s Peter Whiteford got the second round of the 140th Open Championship underway under bright skies at Royal St George’s this morning.

item.title: Veteran Thomas Bjorn and amateur Tom Lewis crown a memorable day
item.description: There were two stars on a remarkable first day of The Open.

item.title: Lewis grabs a share of the lead
item.description: Tom Lewis might want to linger for a while at Royal St George’s tonight.

item.title: Glover heads a strong US challenge
item.description: Lucas Glover is heading a spirited American challenge during the first round of the 140th Open Championship.

item.title: History in their sights
item.description: Thomas Bjorn would be in extremely good company should he maintain his lead right through until Sunday evening.

item.title: Top players finding it hard to make progress
item.description: Defending champion Louis Oosthuizen is struggling to bring his opening round to life.

item.title: Thousands of golf fans queue up for bunker torment
item.description: It’s most golfers’ worst nightmare but fans, course officials and even players at The Open have been queuing up to get stuck in golf’s most notorious bunker.

item.title: Stanley makes the most of his late entry
item.description: Kyle Stanley is no stranger to success and is making the most of his late qualification.

item.title: Former champion Leonard opens with three birdies
item.description: Former Open Champion Justin Leonard is off to a flying start.

item.title: Three former Champions struggle in the wind
item.description: Former Open Champions Ben Curtis, Todd Hamilton and David Duval have had dissapointing first days.

item.title: Dyson leads the home challenge
item.description: Three English players are in a strong position after their first rounds, namely Simon Dyson, Danny Willett and Ian Poulter.

item.title: Fowler has a blast in windswept Kent
item.description: Florida native Rickie Fowler says he enjoyed his pairing with US Open Champion Rory McIlroy.

item.title: Top threesome lurk just behind the leaders
item.description: Pre-Championship favourites Rory McIlroy, Sergio Garcia and Luke Donald have finished their rounds outside the top 5.

item.title: A day of mixed emotions for Bjorn
item.description: The Dane admitted he was proud of his round on a course where he had let a previous chance to win a Major slip away.

item.title: Flawless Jimenez comes home with a 66
item.description: Spaniard Miguel Angel Jimenez has a blemish-free first round, finishing in second place.

item.title: Bjorn exacts a bit of revenge
item.description: Bjorn scores a fantastic 5 under par and takes the early lead of the 140th Open Championship.

item.title: Old hand Calcavecchia shows the way
item.description: Former Open Champion, American Mark Calcavecchia, finishes today with a score of 69.

item.title: Conflicting fortunes for home favourites
item.description: Results have so far been mixed for the pre-Championship favourite, Rory McIlroy.

item.title: Opening pars for Donald and Garcia
item.description: Conditions are proving difficult however world number one Luke Donald is holding his nerve.

item.title: 'Bjorn' again
item.description: Thomas Bjorn is making up for lost time after an impressive beginning.

item.title: McIlroy gets off to sluggish start
item.description: Northern Ireland’s Rory McIlroy made a sluggish start to his Open campaign when he missed a five foot putt for a par on the opening hole.

item.title: Curtis steps back in time
item.description: American, Ben Curtis, took a trip back down memory lane when he drove off the first tee.

item.title: 1989 champion Calcavecchia is out in front
item.description: Mark Calcavecchia, who won the title 22 years ago at Royal Troon and is now a regular on the Champions Tour, has taken the outright lead at two under par after seven holes.

item.title: Uihlein commences amateur challenge
item.description: Five amateurs are hoping to claim the Silver Medal.

item.title: Kelly exorcises his demons at the first
item.description: The 140th Open Championship is under way!

item.title: Six-foot par savers will be key to success says Kaymer
item.description: The key shots in this week's Open Championship are going to be the six-10-foot putts to save par in the opinion of USPGA Championship winner Martin Kaymer of Germany.

item.title: Forecast spells mixed conditions for Royal St George's
item.description: The outlook for the Championship includes a combination of sunshine, showers and wind.

item.title: A glimpse of the mowing brigade
item.description: An insight into what goes on to ensure a quality playing surface at the Open Championship

item.title: Rookie Wootton keeps stellar company
item.description: Adam Wootton returns to Royal St George's in hope of another victory after winning the amateur Grand Challenge in 2008.

item.title: The R&A pays tribute to the legendary Seve Ballesteros.
item.description: The R&A has announced a number of tributes honouring one of golf's greats, the late Seve Ballesteros.

item.title: A dry spell or a serious drought: America at the Majors
item.description: America’s leading golfers will be hoping to restore a bit of national pride when they tee up in this week’s Open Championship at Royal St George’s.

item.title: Low key preparation for US Open winner McIlroy
item.description: Rory McIlroy still found time for a quick nine holes at Royal County Down.
